Your daily sodium intake should ideally be less than 2500mg or 2.5g per day - which is equivalent to 5 grams of salt. Exceeding this intake regularly contributes to high blood pressure and will increase your risk of heart disease and stroke (World Health Organisation).

Your daily caloric intake should ideally be about 2000 a day for women and 2500 a day for men - this varies depending on a number of factors including your age, metabolism, physical activity levels (National Health Service UK). Your intake of calories should not exceed your energy expenditure to prevent weight gain and its associated health problems such as hypertension (World Health Organisation).

You should do at least 150 - 300 minutes of moderately intensive aerobic exercise or at least 75 - 150 minutes of vigorously intense aerobic exercise weekly. Limiting sedentary behaviour will reduce blood pressure, mortality risk and cardiovascular disease mortality, and it will also increase your mental and cognitive health. (World Health Organisation).

Your blood pressure reading consists of two values - the systolic value, on the left of the forward slash above, will always be higher than the diastolic value, on the right above.\n\nYour blood pressure should be below 140/90 mmHg. Keeping your blood pressure below this level will reduce your mortality and your risk of heart attack, heart failure, stroke, and kidney damage. (World Health Organisation).

Alcohol is associated with many health risks, both long and short time, so it is advised to minimise your alcoholic intake as much as possible. The risks of alcohol increase primarily in a dose-dependent manner with the volume consumed and with the frequency of drinking, and alcohol consumption contributes to over 3 million deaths per year globally.(World Health Organisation).

Tobacco is incredibly bad for your health and it kills as many as half of its users. Every year more than 7 million people die as a direct result of tobacco use. Monitoring your tobacco usage can help you to cut back on it and set goals for yourself with the aim or reducing or totally eliminating tobacco from your lifestyle (World Health Organisation).
